what: Homicide in Detroit: The role of Firearms.
title: Preloaded Data Sets
text: dataset called `DETROIT’ book ‘Subset selection regression’ Alan J. Miller published Chapman & Hall series monographs Statistics & Applied Probability, . 40. data unusual subset three predictors can found gives much better fit data subsets found Efroymson stepwise algorithm, forward selection backward elimination. original data given appendix ``Regression analysis application: data-oriented approach’ Gunst & Mason, Statistics textbooks monographs . 24, Marcel Dekker. caused problems copies Gunst & Mason book contain data, Miller say variables used predictors dependent variable. (HOM dependent variable, predictors FTP … ) data frame 13 rows 14 variables: Detroit dataset: FTP: Full-time police per 100,000 population UEMP: UEMP - % unemployed population MAN: MAN - number manufacturing workers thousands LIC: LIC - Number handgun licences per 100,000 population GR: GR - Number handgun registrations per 100,000 population CLEAR: CLEAR - % homicides cleared arrests WM: WM - Number white males population NMAN: NMAN - Number non-manufacturing workers thousands GOV: GOV - Number government workers thousands : - Average hourly earnings : - Average weekly earnings: HOM: HOM - Number homicides per 100,000 population ACC: ACC - Death rate accidents per 100,000 population ASR: ASR - Number assaults per 100,000 population Detroit dataset

title: Preloaded Data Sets
text: data approach student achievement secondary education two Portuguese schools. data attributes include student grades, demographic, social school related features) collected using school reports questionnaires. Two datasets provided regarding performance two distinct subjects: Mathematics (mat) Portuguese language (por). [Cortez Silva, 2008], two datasets modeled binary/five-level classification regression tasks. Important note: target attribute G3 strong correlation attributes G2 G1. occurs G3 final year grade (issued 3rd period), G1 G2 correspond 1st 2nd period grades. difficult predict G3 without G2 G1, prediction much useful (see paper source details) data frame 392 rows 33 variables: Attributes student-mat.csv (Math course) student-por.csv (Portuguese language course) datasets: school - student’s school (binary: ‘GP’ - Gabriel Pereira ‘MS’ - Mousinho da Silveira) sex - student’s sex (binary: ‘F’ - female ‘M’ - male) age - student’s age (numeric: 15 22) address - student’s home address type (binary: ‘U’ - urban ‘R’ - rural) famsize - family size (binary: ‘LE3’ - less equal 3 ‘GT3’ - greater 3) Pstatus - parent’s cohabitation status (binary: ‘T’ - living together ‘’ - apart) Medu - mother’s education (numeric: 0 - none, 1 - primary education (4th grade), 2 = 5th 9th grade, 3 = secondary education 4 = higher education) Fedu - father’s education (numeric: 0 - none, 1 - primary education (4th grade), 2 = 5th 9th grade, 3 = secondary education 4 = higher education) Mjob - mother’s job (nominal: ‘teacher’, ‘health’ care related, civil ‘services’ (e.g. administrative police), ‘at_home’ ‘’) Fjob - father’s job (nominal: ‘teacher’, ‘health’ care related, civil ‘services’ (e.g. administrative police), ‘at_home’ ‘’) reason - reason choose school (nominal: close ‘home’, school ‘reputation’, ‘course’ preference ‘’) guardian - student’s guardian (nominal: ‘mother’, ‘father’ ‘’) traveltime - home school travel time (numeric: 1 - <15 min., 2 - 15 30 min., 3 - 30 min. 1 hour, 4 - >1 hour) studytime - weekly study time (numeric: 1 - <2 hours, 2 - 2 5 hours, 3 - 5 10 hours, 4 - >10 hours) failures - number past class failures (numeric: n 1<=n<3, else 4) schoolsup - extra educational support (binary: yes ) famsup - family educational support (binary: yes ) paid - extra paid classes within course subject (Math Portuguese) (binary: yes ) activities - extra-curricular activities (binary: yes ) nursery - attended nursery school (binary: yes ) higher - wants take higher education (binary: yes ) internet - Internet access home (binary: yes ) romantic - romantic relationship (binary: yes ) famrel - quality family relationships (numeric: 1 - bad 5 - excellent) freetime - free time school (numeric: 1 - low 5 - high) goout - going friends (numeric: 1 - low 5 - high) Dalc - workday alcohol consumption (numeric: 1 - low 5 - high) Walc - weekend alcohol consumption (numeric: 1 - low 5 - high) health - current health status (numeric: 1 - bad 5 - good) absences - number school absences (numeric: 0 93) grades related course subject, Math Portuguese: G1 - first period grade (numeric: 0 20) G2 - second period grade (numeric: 0 20) G3 - final grade (numeric: 0 20, output target) Student dataset Citation Request: Please include citation plan use database: P. Cortez . Silva. Using Data Mining Predict Secondary School Student Performance. . Brito J. Teixeira Eds., Proceedings 5th Future Business Technology Conference (FUBUTEC 2008) pp. 5-12, Porto, Portugal, April, 2008, EUROSIS, ISBN 978-9077381-39-7. Available : Relevant Papers: P. Cortez . Silva. Using Data Mining Predict Secondary School Student Performance. . Brito J. Teixeira Eds., Proceedings 5th Future Business Technology Conference (FUBUTEC 2008) pp. 5-12, Porto, Portugal, April, 2008, EUROSIS, ISBN 978-9077381-39-7. Available : http://www3.dsi.uminho.pt/pcortez/student.pdf Author: http://www3.dsi.uminho.pt/pcortez/Home.html

title: rhandsontable Introduction
text: rhandsontable htmlwidget based handsontable.js library. Handsontable data grid component Excel-like appearance. Built JavaScript, integrates data source peak efficiency. comes powerful features like data validation, sorting, grouping, data binding, formula support column ordering. (via)

title: rhandsontable Introduction
text: table includes support numeric, logical, character Date types. Logical values appear check boxes, pikaday.js library used specify Date values. rhandsontable attempts map R classes appropriate handsontable type. Factors mapped dropdown, choices specified level allowInvalid set FALSE. allow new levels, set allowInvalid TRUE (using hot_col; may also desirable set strict FALSE). running shiny, using hot_to_r preserve custom factor ordering, new levels allowed, added end. improve readability, NA values displayed blank cells. requires converting columns containing NA characters, case factors Dates, may display data desired format. may beneficial convert type columns character passing rhandsontable.
code: DF = data.frame(integer = 1:10,                    numeric = rnorm(10),                    logical = rep(TRUE, 10),                    character = LETTERS[1:10],                    factor = factor(letters[1:10], levels = letters[10:1],                                    ordered = TRUE),                    factor_allow = factor(letters[1:10], levels = letters[10:1],                                          ordered = TRUE),                    date = seq(from = Sys.Date(), by = "days", length.out = 10),                    stringsAsFactors = FALSE)  rhandsontable(DF, width = 600, height = 300) %>%   hot_col("factor_allow", allowInvalid = TRUE) ## Warning in as.character.POSIXt(as.POSIXlt(x), ...): as.character(td, ..) no ## longer obeys a 'format' argument; use format(td, ..) ? DF_na = data.frame(integer = c(NA, 2:10),                    logical = c(NA, rep(TRUE, 9)),                    character = c(NA, LETTERS[1:9]),                    factor = c(NA, factor(letters[1:9])),                    date = c(NA, seq(from = Sys.Date(), by = "days",                                     length.out = 9)),                    stringsAsFactors = FALSE)  DF_na$factor_ch = as.character(DF_na$factor) DF_na$date_ch = c(NA, as.character(seq(from = Sys.Date(), by = "days",                                        length.out = 9)))  rhandsontable(DF_na, width = 550, height = 300)

title: rhandsontable Introduction
text: control character column values, column type can specified dropdown autocomplete.
code: DF = data.frame(val = 1:10, bool = TRUE, big = LETTERS[1:10],                 small = letters[1:10],                 dt = seq(from = Sys.Date(), by = "days", length.out = 10),                 stringsAsFactors = FALSE)  # try updating big to a value not in the dropdown rhandsontable(DF, rowHeaders = NULL, width = 550, height = 300) %>%   hot_col(col = "big", type = "dropdown", source = LETTERS) %>%   hot_col(col = "small", type = "autocomplete", source = letters,           strict = FALSE) ## Warning in as.character.POSIXt(as.POSIXlt(x), ...): as.character(td, ..) no ## longer obeys a 'format' argument; use format(td, ..) ?

title: rhandsontable Introduction
text: column can also specified password type.
code: DF = data.frame(val = 1:10, bool = TRUE, big = LETTERS[1:10],                 small = letters[1:10],                 dt = seq(from = Sys.Date(), by = "days", length.out = 10),                 stringsAsFactors = FALSE)  rhandsontable(DF, width = 550, height = 300) %>%   hot_col("small", "password") ## Warning in as.character.POSIXt(as.POSIXlt(x), ...): as.character(td, ..) no ## longer obeys a 'format' argument; use format(td, ..) ?

title: rhandsontable Introduction
text: New version 0.2, sparkline.js charts can added table. Thanks sparkline package Ramnath Vaidyanathan inspiration.
code: DF = data.frame(val = 1:10, bool = TRUE, big = LETTERS[1:10],                 small = letters[1:10],                 dt = seq(from = Sys.Date(), by = "days", length.out = 10),                 stringsAsFactors = FALSE)  DF$chart = c(sapply(1:5,                     function(x) jsonlite::toJSON(list(values=rnorm(10),                                                       options = list(type = "bar")))),              sapply(1:5,                     function(x) jsonlite::toJSON(list(values=rnorm(10),                                                       options = list(type = "line")))))  rhandsontable(DF, rowHeaders = NULL, width = 550, height = 300) %>%   hot_col("chart", renderer = htmlwidgets::JS("renderSparkline")) ## Warning in as.character.POSIXt(as.POSIXlt(x), ...): as.character(td, ..) no ## longer obeys a 'format' argument; use format(td, ..) ?

title: rhandsontable Introduction
text: ’s also possible define custom column renderer function. example, may desirable include html cell. example mimics Custom renderers. shiny apps, use renderer = htmlwidgets::JS("safeHtmlRenderer") display columns html data. allowed html tags default <em><b><strong><><big>, (hidden) allowedTags parameter can rhandsontable can used customize list.
code: DF = data.frame( title = c( "Professional JavaScript for Web Developers", "JavaScript: The Good Parts", "JavaScript: The Definitive Guide" ), desc = c( "This book provides a developer-level introduction along with more advanced and useful features of JavaScript.", "This book provides a developer-level introduction along with more advanced and useful features of JavaScript.", "JavaScript: The Definitive Guide provides a thorough description of the core JavaScript language and both the legacy and standard DOMs implemented in web browsers." ), comments = c( "I would rate it ★★★★☆", "This is the book about JavaScript", "I've never actually read it, but the comments are highly positive." ), cover = c( "http://ecx.images-amazon.com/images/I/51bRhyVTVGL._SL50_.jpg", "http://ecx.images-amazon.com/images/I/51gdVAEfPUL._SL50_.jpg", "http://ecx.images-amazon.com/images/I/51VFNL4T7kL._SL50_.jpg" ), stringsAsFactors = FALSE ) rhandsontable(DF, allowedTags = "", width = 800, height = 450, rowHeaders = FALSE) %>% hot_cols(colWidths = c(200, 200, 200, 80)) %>% hot_col(1:2, renderer = "html") %>% hot_col(1:3, renderer = htmlwidgets::JS("safeHtmlRenderer")) %>% hot_col(4, renderer = " function(instance, td, row, col, prop, value, cellProperties) { var escaped = Handsontable.helper.stringify(value), img; if (escaped.indexOf('http') === 0) { img = document.createElement('IMG'); img.src = value; Handsontable.dom.addEvent(img, 'mousedown', function (e){ e.preventDefault(); // prevent selection quirk }); Handsontable.dom.empty(td); td.appendChild(img); } else { // render as text Handsontable.renderers.TextRenderer.apply(this, arguments); } return td; }")

what: Custom Renderer using an R Parameter
title: rhandsontable Introduction
text: Additional parameters passed rhandsontable available JavaScript widget via params property. using approach shiny app document one widget, widget search logic need robust.
code: DF = data.frame(val = 1:10, bool = TRUE, big = LETTERS[1:10],                 small = letters[1:10],                 dt = seq(from = Sys.Date(), by = "days", length.out = 10),                 stringsAsFactors = FALSE)  col_highlight = 2 row_highlight = c(5, 7)  rhandsontable(DF, col_highlight = col_highlight,               row_highlight = row_highlight,               width = 550, height = 300) %>%   hot_cols(renderer = "     function(instance, td, row, col, prop, value, cellProperties) {       Handsontable.renderers.TextRenderer.apply(this, arguments);        tbl = this.HTMLWidgets.widgets[0]        hcols = tbl.params.col_highlight       hcols = hcols instanceof Array ? hcols : [hcols]       hrows = tbl.params.row_highlight       hrows = hrows instanceof Array ? hrows : [hrows]        if (hcols.includes(col) && hrows.includes(row)) {         td.style.background = 'red';       }       else if (hcols.includes(col)) {         td.style.background = 'lightgreen';       }       else if (hrows.includes(row)) {         td.style.background = 'pink';       }        return td;   }") ## Warning in as.character.POSIXt(as.POSIXlt(x), ...): as.character(td, ..) no ## longer obeys a 'format' argument; use format(td, ..) ? HTMLWidgets.widgets.filter(function(widget) {   // this should match the table id specified in the shiny app   return widget.name === "hot" })[0];

title: rhandsontable Introduction
text: Right-clicking cell enable context menu includes customizable table actions via hot_context_menu function. shiny apps, formatting comment updates made via context menu currently retained. disable context menu, set contextMenu = FALSE hot_table (rhandsontable).

title: rhandsontable Introduction
text: default user can add remove table rows columns, functionality can disabled. Note Handsontable allow column added deleted table column types defined (.e. useTypes == TRUE rhandsontable).
code: DF = data.frame(val = 1:10, bool = TRUE, big = LETTERS[1:10],                 small = letters[1:10],                 dt = seq(from = Sys.Date(), by = "days", length.out = 10),                 stringsAsFactors = FALSE)  rhandsontable(DF, width = 550, height = 300) %>%   hot_context_menu(allowRowEdit = FALSE, allowColEdit = FALSE) ## Warning in as.character.POSIXt(as.POSIXlt(x), ...): as.character(td, ..) no ## longer obeys a 'format' argument; use format(td, ..) ?

title: rhandsontable Introduction
text: customOpts parameter hot_context_menu can used add custom functionality context menu. couple examples.

title: rhandsontable Introduction
text: example illustrates add option export table csv file.
code: MAT = matrix(rnorm(50), nrow = 10, dimnames = list(LETTERS[1:10],                                                    letters[1:5]))  rhandsontable(MAT, width = 550, height = 300) %>%   hot_context_menu(     customOpts = list(       csv = list(name = "Download to CSV",                     callback = htmlwidgets::JS(                       "function (key, options) {                          var csv = csvString(this);                           var link = document.createElement('a');                          link.setAttribute('href', 'data:text/plain;charset=utf-8,' +                            encodeURIComponent(csv));                          link.setAttribute('download', 'data.csv');                           document.body.appendChild(link);                          link.click();                          document.body.removeChild(link);                        }"))))

title: rhandsontable Introduction
text: example illustrates enable search functionality Handsontable. Future enhancements look expand export options.
code: DF = data.frame(val = 1:10,                 bool = TRUE,                 big = LETTERS[1:10],                 small = factor(letters[1:10]),                 dt = seq(from = Sys.Date(), by = "days", length.out = 10),                 stringsAsFactors = FALSE)  rhandsontable(DF, search = TRUE, width = 550, height = 300) %>%   hot_context_menu(     customOpts = list(       search = list(name = "Search",                     callback = htmlwidgets::JS(                       "function (key, options) {                          var srch = prompt('Search criteria');                           this.search.query(srch);                          this.render();                        }"))))

title: rhandsontable Introduction
text: Numeric columns formatted using numbro.js library.
code: DF = data.frame(int = 1:10, float = rnorm(10), cur = rnorm(10) * 1E5,                 lrg = rnorm(10) * 1E8, pct = rnorm(10))  rhandsontable(DF, width = 550, height = 300) %>%   hot_col("float", format = "0.0") %>%   hot_col("cur", format = "$0,0.00") %>%   hot_col("lrg", format = "0a") %>%   hot_col("pct", format = "0%")

title: rhandsontable Introduction
text: language parameter hot_col can used change locale. See numeral.js library language options.
code: DF = data.frame(dollar = rnorm(10), euro = rnorm(10), yen = rnorm(10))  rhandsontable(DF * 1000, width = 550, height = 300) %>%   hot_col("dollar", format = "$0,000.00", language = "en-US") %>%   hot_col("euro", format = "0,000.00 $", language = "de-DE") %>%   hot_col("yen", format = "$0,000.00", language = "ja-JP")

title: rhandsontable Introduction
text: whole table individual columns can set readOnly prevent user making changes.
code: DF = data.frame(val = 1:10, bool = TRUE, big = LETTERS[1:10],                 small = letters[1:10],                 dt = seq(from = Sys.Date(), by = "days", length.out = 10),                 stringsAsFactors = FALSE)  rhandsontable(DF, readOnly = TRUE, width = 550, height = 300) %>%   hot_col("val", readOnly = FALSE) ## Warning in as.character.POSIXt(as.POSIXlt(x), ...): as.character(td, ..) no ## longer obeys a 'format' argument; use format(td, ..) ?

title: rhandsontable Introduction
text: Column sorting can enabled; sorting impacts widget reorder original data set.
code: DF = data.frame(val = 1:10, bool = TRUE, big = LETTERS[1:10],                 small = letters[1:10],                 dt = seq(from = Sys.Date(), by = "days", length.out = 10),                 stringsAsFactors = FALSE)  rhandsontable(DF, width = 550, height = 300) %>%   hot_cols(columnSorting = TRUE) ## Warning in as.character.POSIXt(as.POSIXlt(x), ...): as.character(td, ..) no ## longer obeys a 'format' argument; use format(td, ..) ?

title: rhandsontable Introduction
text: larger tables desirable highlight row column selected cell. See Custom Renderer using R Parameter static highlighting example.
code: DF = data.frame(val = 1:10, bool = TRUE, big = LETTERS[1:10],                 small = letters[1:10],                 dt = seq(from = Sys.Date(), by = "days", length.out = 10),                 stringsAsFactors = FALSE)  # click on a cell to see the highlighting rhandsontable(DF, width = 550, height = 300) %>%   hot_table(highlightCol = TRUE, highlightRow = TRUE) ## Warning in as.character.POSIXt(as.POSIXlt(x), ...): as.character(td, ..) no ## longer obeys a 'format' argument; use format(td, ..) ?

title: rhandsontable Introduction
text: Column row dimensions can customized. larger data sets, (multiple) top rows left columns can frozen.
code: MAT = matrix(rnorm(50), nrow = 10, dimnames = list(LETTERS[1:10],                                                    letters[1:5]))  rhandsontable(MAT, width = 600, height = 600) %>%   hot_cols(colWidths = 100) %>%   hot_rows(rowHeights = 50)

title: rhandsontable Introduction
text: width row header column can customized using rowHeaderWidth.
code: rhandsontable(mtcars, rowHeaderWidth = 200)

title: rhandsontable Introduction
text: table can streched full width using stretchH.
code: MAT = matrix(rnorm(30), nrow = 10, dimnames = list(LETTERS[1:10],                                                    letters[1:3]))  rhandsontable(MAT, width = 600, height = 300, stretchH = "all")

title: rhandsontable Introduction
text: larger data sets, (multiple) top rows left columns can frozen.
code: MAT = matrix(rnorm(26 * 26), nrow = 26, dimnames = list(LETTERS, letters))  # scroll through the table to see the fixed row and column rhandsontable(MAT, width = 550, height = 300) %>%   hot_cols(fixedColumnsLeft = 1) %>%   hot_rows(fixedRowsTop = 1)

title: rhandsontable Introduction
text: Comments (hover) can also added individual cells appear red flags upper right cell. Additionally, comments can added via data.frame matrix. Finally, comments can also added via right-click context menu, updates currently retained shiny.
code: DF = data.frame(val = 1:10, bool = TRUE, big = LETTERS[1:10],                 small = letters[1:10],                 dt = seq(from = Sys.Date(), by = "days", length.out = 10),                 stringsAsFactors = FALSE)  rhandsontable(DF, width = 550, height = 300) %>%   hot_cell(1, 1, "Test comment") ## Warning in as.character.POSIXt(as.POSIXlt(x), ...): as.character(td, ..) no ## longer obeys a 'format' argument; use format(td, ..) ? MAT_comments = matrix(ncol = ncol(DF), nrow = nrow(DF)) MAT_comments[1, 1] = "Test comment" MAT_comments[2, 2] = "Another test comment"  rhandsontable(DF, comments = MAT_comments, width = 550, height = 300) ## Warning in as.character.POSIXt(as.POSIXlt(x), ...): as.character(td, ..) no ## longer obeys a 'format' argument; use format(td, ..) ?

title: rhandsontable Introduction
text: Custom borders can drawn around cells highlight specific items. Borders can also added via right-click context menu, updates currently retained shiny.
code: MAT = matrix(rnorm(50), nrow = 10, dimnames = list(LETTERS[1:10],                                                    letters[1:5]))  rhandsontable(MAT, width = 550, height = 300) %>%   hot_table(customBorders = list(list(     range = list(from = list(row = 1, col = 1),                  to = list(row = 2, col = 2)),     top = list(width = 2, color = "red"),     left = list(width = 2, color = "red"),     bottom = list(width = 2, color = "red"),     right = list(width = 2, color = "red"))))

title: rhandsontable Introduction
text: Pre-defined validation can added numeric columns two ways: specify min max values within range exclude similar dropdown column, specify allowed values
code: MAT = matrix(rnorm(50), nrow = 10, dimnames = list(LETTERS[1:10],                                                    letters[1:5]))  rhandsontable(MAT * 10, width = 550, height = 300) %>%   hot_validate_numeric(col = 1, min = -50, max = 50, exclude = 40) rhandsontable(MAT * 10, width = 550, height = 300) %>%   hot_validate_numeric(col = 1, choices = c(10, 20, 40))

title: rhandsontable Introduction
text: character columns, vector allowed options can specified. user-friendly approach may use dropdown column strict = TRUE.
code: DF = data.frame(val = 1:10, bool = TRUE, big = LETTERS[1:10],                 small = letters[1:10],                 dt = seq(from = Sys.Date(), by = "days", length.out = 10),                 stringsAsFactors = FALSE)  rhandsontable(DF, width = 550, height = 300) %>%   hot_validate_character(col = "big", choices = LETTERS[1:10]) ## Warning in as.character.POSIXt(as.POSIXlt(x), ...): as.character(td, ..) no ## longer obeys a 'format' argument; use format(td, ..) ?

title: rhandsontable Introduction
text: also possible create custom validation function JavaScript.
code: MAT = matrix(rnorm(50), nrow = 10, dimnames = list(LETTERS[1:10],                                                    letters[1:5]))  # try to update any cell to 0 rhandsontable(MAT * 10, width = 550, height = 300) %>%   hot_cols(validator = "            function (value, callback) {             setTimeout(function(){               callback(value != 0);             }, 1000)            }",            allowInvalid = FALSE)

title: rhandsontable Introduction
text: Conditional formatting can also specified via custom JavaScript function. Future enhancements look simplify interface. See Custom Renderer using R Parameter another example.
code: MAT = matrix(runif(100, -1, 1), nrow = 10,              dimnames = list(LETTERS[1:10], LETTERS[1:10])) diag(MAT) = 1 MAT[upper.tri(MAT)] = MAT[lower.tri(MAT)] rhandsontable(MAT, readOnly = TRUE, width = 750, height = 300) %>%   hot_cols(renderer = "            function (instance, td, row, col, prop, value, cellProperties) {              Handsontable.renderers.TextRenderer.apply(this, arguments);              if (row == col) {               td.style.background = 'lightgrey';              } else if (col > row) {               td.style.background = 'grey';               td.style.color = 'grey';              } else if (value < -0.75) {               td.style.background = 'pink';              } else if (value > 0.75) {               td.style.background = 'lightgreen';              }            }")

title: rhandsontable Introduction
text: chroma.js library can used turn table heatmap.
code: MAT = matrix(rnorm(50), nrow = 10, dimnames = list(LETTERS[1:10],                                                    letters[1:5]))  rhandsontable(MAT, width = 550, height = 300) %>%   hot_heatmap()

title: rhandsontable Introduction
code: MAT = matrix(rnorm(10000 * 100), nrow = 100, dimnames= list(1:100, 1:10000))  rhandsontable(MAT, width = 550, height = 550)

title: rhandsontable Introduction
text: Important note shiny use: htmlwidgets package creates widgets shiny output bindings. rhandsontable package also attempts expose table pseudo shiny input binding using handsontable change events (see supported events). means table (e.g. hot) can accessed shiny using either input$hot output$hot, values may -sync. timing updates depend particular reactive path followed shiny application. Since widget currently able use standard shiny input binding functionality, need explicitly call hot_to_r function convert handsontable data R object. Two additional inputs also enabled, input$hot_select input$hot_comment, fire cell selection comment changes, respectively (like see options, please post issue create PR). functionality still evolving, please don’t hesitate share suggestions PRs. data grid editable default can used input shiny app. shiny shinydashboard example links listed . Note shinyapps.io links may work hit monthly usage limit. Output Date file editor Calculation input Table callback linked chart Multiple input tables shinydashboard app
code: shiny::runGitHub("rhandsontable", "jrowen",                  subdir = "inst/examples/rhandsontable_output") shiny::runGitHub("rhandsontable", "jrowen",                  subdir = "inst/examples/rhandsontable_datafile") shiny::runGitHub("rhandsontable", "jrowen",                  subdir = "inst/examples/rhandsontable_portfolio") shiny::runGitHub("rhandsontable", "jrowen",                  subdir = "inst/examples/rhandsontable_corr") shiny::runGitHub("rhandsontable", "jrowen",                  subdir = "inst/examples/rhandsontable_frontier") shiny::runGitHub("rhandsontable", "jrowen",                  subdir="inst/examples/rhandsontable_dash")

title: rhandsontable Introduction
text: Version 0.14 shiny includes new bookmarking functionality. willl work rhandsontable special handling. See issue details.

title: rhandsontable Introduction
text: Please file issue experience problems widget feature requests. Pull requests also welcome.

title: routlier
text: routlier package built look outliers dataset. functions allow user look outliers ‘x’ number deviations away mean data particular column. number ‘Outliers’ dataset returned. Additionally Outlier value now replaced word ‘Outlier’ dataset.
code: library(routlier)  routlier::routlier_simple(data = detroit,sd = 1) ## You have  66  outliers in your dataset ##        FTP    UEMP     MAN     LIC      GR   CLEAR      WM    NMAN     GOV ## 1   260.35 Outlier Outlier Outlier Outlier    93.4 Outlier Outlier Outlier ## 2    269.8       7 Outlier Outlier Outlier    88.5 Outlier Outlier Outlier ## 3   272.04     5.2 Outlier Outlier Outlier Outlier Outlier Outlier Outlier ## 4   272.96     4.3   535.8   222.1 Outlier      92  500457     591   150.3 ## 5   272.51     3.5     576  301.92  297.65      91  482418   626.1   164.3 ## 6   261.34 Outlier   601.7  391.22  367.62    87.4  465029   659.8   179.5 ## 7   268.89     4.1   577.3  665.56  616.54    88.3  448267   686.2   187.5 ## 8   295.99     3.9   596.9 Outlier Outlier    86.1  432109   699.6   195.4 ## 9   319.87     3.6 Outlier   837.6  786.23      79  416533   729.9   210.3 ## 10  341.43     7.1   569.3   794.9  713.77    73.9  401518   757.8 Outlier ## 11 Outlier Outlier   548.8  817.74  750.43 Outlier Outlier   755.3 Outlier ## 12 Outlier     7.7   563.4  583.17 Outlier Outlier Outlier Outlier Outlier ## 13 Outlier     6.3 Outlier  709.59   666.5 Outlier Outlier Outlier Outlier ##         HE      WE     HOM     ACC     ASR ## 1  Outlier Outlier Outlier Outlier  306.18 ## 2     3.09  134.02     8.9 Outlier  315.16 ## 3     3.23  141.68 Outlier   45.31  277.53 ## 4     3.33  147.98    8.89   49.51 Outlier ## 5     3.46  159.85   13.07 Outlier Outlier ## 6      3.6  157.19   14.57 Outlier Outlier ## 7     3.73  155.29   21.36   50.62  286.11 ## 8  Outlier  131.75   28.03   51.47  291.59 ## 9     4.25  178.74   31.49   49.16  320.39 ## 10    4.47   178.3   37.39    45.8  323.03 ## 11 Outlier  209.54 Outlier   44.54  357.38 ## 12 Outlier Outlier Outlier Outlier Outlier ## 13 Outlier Outlier Outlier   44.17 Outlier

what: routlier:: Example with both quantitative and qualitative data
title: routlier
text: utilize student dataset included routlier package. dataset quantitative qualitative data . can see 274 outliers set sd argument equal 2.

what: routlier:: Using routlier_dt_sd() we can find the Outliers in a dataset and have them highlighted with a green background to make them easier to find. Here we have an interactive DT::table that gets returned. This allows us to filter and sort out data much more easily.
title: routlier
code: routlier_dt_sd(data = detroit,sd = 1) ## You have  66  outliers in your dataset

what: routlier:: Using routlier_formattable() we can find the Outliers in a dataset and have the Outliers highlighted in red and the non-outlier values highlighted in green.
title: routlier
code: routlier_formattable(data = detroit,sd = 2) ## You have  4  outliers in your dataset ##  [1] "WM"    "WE"    "UEMP"  "NMAN"  "MAN"   "LIC"   "HOM"   "HE"    "GR"    ## [10] "GOV"   "FTP"   "CLEAR" "ASR"   "ACC"   ##  [1] "WM"    "WE"    "UEMP"  "NMAN"  "MAN"   "LIC"   "HOM"   "HE"    "GR"    ## [10] "GOV"   "FTP"   "CLEAR" "ASR"   "ACC"

what: routlier:: Using routlier_mad() we can find the Outliers in a dataset and have the Outliers highlighted in red and the non-outlier values highlighted in green.
title: routlier
code: routlier_mad(data = detroit,MAD = 3) ## [1] "The MAD for column 1 is from: 329.046758 : 216.873242 and the overall MAD range is: 112.173516" ## [1] "The MAD for column 2 is from: 12.76126 : -2.36126 and the overall MAD range is: 15.12252" ## [1] "The MAD for column 3 is from: 713.40872 : 425.19128 and the overall MAD range is: 288.217440000001" ## [1] "The MAD for column 4 is from: 1714.823754 : -548.483754 and the overall MAD range is: 2263.307508" ## [1] "The MAD for column 5 is from: 2034.898942 : -801.818942 and the overall MAD range is: 2836.717884" ## [1] "The MAD for column 6 is from: 114.0868 : 60.7132 and the overall MAD range is: 53.3736" ## [1] "The MAD for column 7 is from: 680397.682 : 216136.318 and the overall MAD range is: 464261.364" ## [1] "The MAD for column 8 is from: 1004.66248 : 367.73752 and the overall MAD range is: 636.924959999999" ## [1] "The MAD for column 9 is from: 352.95816 : 22.0418400000001 and the overall MAD range is: 330.91632" ## [1] "The MAD for column 10 is from: 6.357636 : 0.842363999999999 and the overall MAD range is: 5.515272" ## [1] "The MAD for column 11 is from: 253.04009 : 61.3399099999999 and the overall MAD range is: 191.70018" ## [1] "The MAD for column 12 is from: 76.824066 : -34.104066 and the overall MAD range is: 110.928132" ## [1] "The MAD for column 13 is from: 67.016006 : 24.583994 and the overall MAD range is: 42.432012" ## [1] "The MAD for column 14 is from: 433.60947 : 178.75053 and the overall MAD range is: 254.85894" ## [1] "You have a total of 7 Outliers in your dataset" ## $outliers ## [1] 7 ##  ## $outlier_table

what: routlier:: Using routlier_quantile() we can find the Outliers in a dataset and have the Outliers highlighted in red and the non-outlier values highlighted in green. We can look at either M mild outlier or E extreme outliers.
title: routlier
text: approach utilizes Tukey method looking quantile ranges utilizing upper quartile lower quartile ranges.
code: routlier_quantile(data = mtcars[1:10,],type = 7,outlier_type = "M") ## [1] "The IQR for column 1 is from: 27.8875 : 13.3875 and the overall IQR range is: 14.5" ## [1] "The IQR for column 2 is from: 8.25 : 2.25 and the overall IQR range is: 6" ## [1] "The IQR for column 3 is from: 399.3375 : 0.437499999999943 and the overall IQR range is: 398.9" ## [1] "The IQR for column 4 is from: 153.125 : 64.125 and the overall IQR range is: 89" ## [1] "The IQR for column 5 is from: 5.0025 : 2.0625 and the overall IQR range is: 2.94" ## [1] "The IQR for column 6 is from: 4.184375 : 2.199375 and the overall IQR range is: 1.985" ## [1] "The IQR for column 7 is from: 24.12 : 12.76 and the overall IQR range is: 11.36" ## [1] "The IQR for column 8 is from: 2.5 : -1.5 and the overall IQR range is: 4" ## [1] "The IQR for column 9 is from: 1.875 : -1.125 and the overall IQR range is: 3" ## [1] "The IQR for column 10 is from: 5.5 : 1.5 and the overall IQR range is: 4" ## [1] "The IQR for column 11 is from: 8.125 : -2.875 and the overall IQR range is: 11" ## [1] "You have a total of 3 Outliers in your dataset"

title: Identify outliers in a dataset
text: routlier package built look outliers dataset. functions allow user look outliers ‘x’ number deviations away mean data particular column. number ‘Outliers’ dataset returned. Additionally Outlier value now replaced word ‘Outlier’ dataset. also function routlier_mad() utilizes MAD median absolute deviation approach look Outliers. MAD approach less susceptible extreme outliers traditional Median & SD approach. See following thesis explanation. Thesis
code: library(routlier)  routlier::routlier_simple(data = detroit,sd = 1)

what: routlier:: Example with both quantitative and qualitative data
title: Identify outliers in a dataset
text: utilize student dataset included routlier package. dataset quantitative qualitative data . can see 274 outliers set sd argument equal 2 student dataset.
code: routlier_simple(data = detroit,sd = 2) routlier_simple(data = student,sd = 2)

what: Homicide in Detroit: The role of Firearms.
title: Identify outliers in a dataset
text: dataset called ‘DETROIT’ book ‘Subset selection regression’ Alan J. Miller published Chapman & Hall series monographs Statistics & Applied Probability, . 40. data unusual subset three predictors can found gives much better fit data subsets found Efroymson stepwise algorithm, forward selection backward elimination. original data given appendix `Regression analysis application: data-oriented approach’ Gunst & Mason, Statistics textbooks monographs . 24, Marcel Dekker. caused problems copies Gunst & Mason book contain data, Miller say variables used predictors dependent variable. (HOM dependent variable, predictors FTP … ) data frame 13 rows 14 variables: FTP: Full-time police per 100,000 population UEMP: UEMP - % unemployed population MAN: MAN - number manufacturing workers thousands LIC: LIC - Number handgun licences per 100,000 population GR: GR - Number handgun registrations per 100,000 population CLEAR: CLEAR - % homicides cleared arrests WM: WM - Number white males population NMAN: NMAN - Number non-manufacturing workers thousands GOV: GOV - Number government workers thousands : - Average hourly earnings : - Average weekly earnings: HOM: HOM - Number homicides per 100,000 population ACC: ACC - Death rate accidents per 100,000 population ASR: ASR - Number assaults per 100,000 population Detroit dataset

previous_headings: routlier:: Example with both quantitative and qualitative data
title: Identify outliers in a dataset
text: Student Performance dataset data approach student achievement secondary education two Portuguese schools. data attributes include student grades, demographic, social school related features) collected using school reports questionnaires. Two datasets provided regarding performance two distinct subjects: Mathematics (mat) Portuguese language (por). [Cortez Silva, 2008], two datasets modeled binary/five-level classification regression tasks. Important note: target attribute G3 strong correlation attributes G2 G1. occurs G3 final year grade (issued 3rd period), G1 G2 correspond 1st 2nd period grades. difficult predict G3 without G2 G1, prediction much useful (see paper source details) data frame 392 rows 33 variables:  Attributes student-mat.csv (Math course) student-por.csv (Portuguese language course) datasets: school - student’s school (binary: ‘GP’ - Gabriel Pereira ‘MS’ - Mousinho da Silveira) sex - student’s sex (binary: ‘F’ - female ‘M’ - male) age - student’s age (numeric: 15 22) address - student’s home address type (binary: ‘U’ - urban ‘R’ - rural) famsize - family size (binary: ‘LE3’ - less equal 3 ‘GT3’ - greater 3) Pstatus - parent’s cohabitation status (binary: ‘T’ - living together ‘’ - apart) Medu - mother’s education (numeric: 0 - none, 1 - primary education (4th grade), 2 - 5th 9th grade, 3 - secondary education 4 - higher education) Fedu - father’s education (numeric: 0 - none, 1 - primary education (4th grade), 2 â€“ 5th 9th grade, 3 â€“ secondary education 4 â€“ higher education) Mjob - mother’s job (nominal: ‘teacher’, ‘health’ care related, civil ‘services’ (e.g. administrative police), ‘at_home’ ‘’) Fjob - father’s job (nominal: ‘teacher’, ‘health’ care related, civil ‘services’ (e.g. administrative police), ‘at_home’ ‘’) reason - reason choose school (nominal: close ‘home’, school ‘reputation’, ‘course’ preference ‘’) guardian - student’s guardian (nominal: ‘mother’, ‘father’ ‘’) traveltime - home school travel time (numeric: 1 - <15 min., 2 - 15 30 min., 3 - 30 min. 1 hour, 4 - >1 hour) studytime - weekly study time (numeric: 1 - <2 hours, 2 - 2 5 hours, 3 - 5 10 hours, 4 - >10 hours) failures - number past class failures (numeric: n 1<=n<3, else 4) schoolsup - extra educational support (binary: yes ) famsup - family educational support (binary: yes ) paid - extra paid classes within course subject (Math Portuguese) (binary: yes ) activities - extra-curricular activities (binary: yes ) nursery - attended nursery school (binary: yes ) higher - wants take higher education (binary: yes ) internet - Internet access home (binary: yes ) romantic - romantic relationship (binary: yes ) famrel - quality family relationships (numeric: 1 - bad 5 - excellent) freetime - free time school (numeric: 1 - low 5 - high) goout - going friends (numeric: 1 - low 5 - high) Dalc - workday alcohol consumption (numeric: 1 - low 5 - high) Walc - weekend alcohol consumption (numeric: 1 - low 5 - high) health - current health status (numeric: 1 - bad 5 - good) absences - number school absences (numeric: 0 93)  grades related course subject, Math Portuguese: Grades: + G1 - first period grade (numeric: 0 20) + G2 - second period grade (numeric: 0 20) + G3 - final grade (numeric: 0 20, output target) Student dataset References: Citation Request: Please include citation plan use database: P. Cortez . Silva. Using Data Mining Predict Secondary School Student Performance. . Brito J. Teixeira Eds., Proceedings 5th Future Business Technology Conference (FUBUTEC 2008) pp. 5-12, Porto, Portugal, April, 2008, EUROSIS, ISBN 978-9077381-39-7. Available : http://www3.dsi.uminho.pt/pcortez/student.pdf Relevant Papers: P. Cortez . Silva. Using Data Mining Predict Secondary School Student Performance. . Brito J. Teixeira Eds., Proceedings 5th Future Business Technology Conference (FUBUTEC 2008) pp. 5-12, Porto, Portugal, April, 2008, EUROSIS, ISBN 978-9077381-39-7. Available : http://www3.dsi.uminho.pt/pcortez/student.pdf http://www3.dsi.uminho.pt/pcortez/Home.html <!– badges: start

title: Returns an outlier data frame in a DT table utilizing the mean absolute deviation (MAD) method — routlier_mad
code: data<- routlier_mad(data = mtcars,MAD = 2) #> [1] "The MAD for column 1 is from: 30.02298 : 8.37702 and the overall MAD range is: 21.64596" #> [1] "The MAD for column 2 is from: 11.9304 : 0.0696000000000003 and the overall MAD range is: 11.8608" #> [1] "The MAD for column 3 is from: 477.2527 : -84.6527 and the overall MAD range is: 561.9054" #> [1] "The MAD for column 4 is from: 277.1904 : -31.1904 and the overall MAD range is: 308.3808" #> [1] "The MAD for column 5 is from: 5.10347 : 2.28653 and the overall MAD range is: 2.81694" #> [1] "The MAD for column 6 is from: 4.859491 : 1.790509 and the overall MAD range is: 3.068982" #> [1] "The MAD for column 7 is from: 20.541766 : 14.878234 and the overall MAD range is: 5.663532" #> [1] "The MAD for column 8 is from: 0 : 0 and the overall MAD range is: 0" #> [1] "The MAD for column 9 is from: 0 : 0 and the overall MAD range is: 0" #> [1] "The MAD for column 10 is from: 6.9652 : 1.0348 and the overall MAD range is: 5.9304" #> [1] "The MAD for column 11 is from: 4.9652 : -0.9652 and the overall MAD range is: 5.9304" #> [1] "You have a total of 15 Outliers in your dataset"    print(data$outliers) #> [1] 15

what: Returns a formattable data frame that highlights the outliers utilizing the quantile method. — routlier_quantile
title: Returns a formattable data frame that highlights the outliers utilizing the quantile method. — routlier_quantile
text: word 'Outlier' replace value outlier respective cell.

title: Returns a formattable data frame that highlights the outliers utilizing the quantile method. — routlier_quantile
code: routlier_quantile(data,type,outlier_type)

title: Returns a formattable data frame that highlights the outliers utilizing the quantile method. — routlier_quantile
text: data filepath data type select type quantile method use. Choices 1 7. outlier_type select type outlier selecting either "M" mild "E" extreme.

title: Returns a formattable data frame that highlights the outliers utilizing the quantile method. — routlier_quantile
text: Return's outlier dataset original dataset formattable table. data returned currently numeric data dataset.

title: Returns a formattable data frame that highlights the outliers utilizing the quantile method. — routlier_quantile
code: ## Load the routlier library    library(routlier)  ## Look at outliers utilizng the Tukey method   routlier_quantile(data = iris,type = 7,outlier_type="M") #> [1] "The IQR for column 1 is from: 8.35 : 3.15 and the overall IQR range is: 5.2" #> [1] "The IQR for column 2 is from: 4.05 : 2.05 and the overall IQR range is: 2" #> [1] "The IQR for column 3 is from: 10.35 : -3.65 and the overall IQR range is: 14" #> [1] "The IQR for column 4 is from: 4.05 : -1.95 and the overall IQR range is: 6" #> [1] "You have a total of 4 Outliers in your dataset"

title: Finds the Outliers in a dataset utilizing the Tukey's Method — routlier_tukey
code: ## Load the routlier library    library(routlier)  ## Look at outliers utilizng the Tukey method   routlier_tukey(data = detroit,type = 7,outlier_type="M") #> [1] "The IQR for column 1 is from: 448.875 : 162.355 and the overall IQR range is: 286.52" #> [1] "The IQR for column 2 is from: 11.9 : -0.9 and the overall IQR range is: 12.8" #> [1] "The IQR for column 3 is from: 688.55 : 444.15 and the overall IQR range is: 244.4" #> [1] "The IQR for column 4 is from: 1654.1 : -637.1 and the overall IQR range is: 2291.2" #> [1] "The IQR for column 5 is from: 1528.57 : -546.47 and the overall IQR range is: 2075.04" #> [1] "The IQR for column 6 is from: 116.65 : 48.25 and the overall IQR range is: 68.4" #> [1] "The IQR for column 7 is from: 648865.5 : 253109.5 and the overall IQR range is: 395756" #> [1] "The IQR for column 8 is from: 1001.75 : 344.55 and the overall IQR range is: 657.2" #> [1] "The IQR for column 9 is from: 334.05 : 40.05 and the overall IQR range is: 294" #> [1] "The IQR for column 10 is from: 6.33 : 1.37 and the overall IQR range is: 4.96" #> [1] "The IQR for column 11 is from: 234.33 : 86.09 and the overall IQR range is: 148.24" #> [1] "The IQR for column 12 is from: 80.125 : -33.835 and the overall IQR range is: 113.96" #> [1] "The IQR for column 13 is from: 60.295 : 34.495 and the overall IQR range is: 25.8" #> [1] "The IQR for column 14 is from: 391.28 : 209.28 and the overall IQR range is: 182" #> [1] "You have a total of 4 Outliers in your dataset"

title: Student Performance dataset . — student
text: data approach student achievement secondary education two Portuguese schools. data attributes include student grades, demographic, social school related features) collected using school reports questionnaires. Two datasets provided regarding performance two distinct subjects: Mathematics (mat) Portuguese language (por). Cortez Silva, 2008, two datasets modeled binary/five-level classification regression tasks. Important note: target attribute G3 strong correlation attributes G2 G1. occurs G3 final year grade (issued 3rd period), G1 G2 correspond 1st 2nd period grades. difficult predict G3 without G2 G1, prediction much useful (see paper source details)

title: Student Performance dataset . — student
code: student

title: Student Performance dataset . — student
text: data frame 392 rows 33 variables: school - student's school (binary: 'GP' - Gabriel Pereira 'MS' - Mousinho da Silveira) sex - student's sex (binary: 'F' - female 'M' - male) age - student's age (numeric: 15 22) address - student's home address type (binary: 'U' - urban 'R' - rural) famsize - family size (binary: 'LE3' - less equal 3 'GT3' - greater 3) Pstatus - parent's cohabitation status (binary: 'T' - living together '' - apart) Medu - mother's education (numeric: 0 - none, 1 - primary education (4th grade), 2 â€“ 5th 9th grade, 3 â€“ secondary education 4 â€“ higher education) Fedu - father's education (numeric: 0 - none, 1 - primary education (4th grade), 2 â€“ 5th 9th grade, 3 â€“ secondary education 4 â€“ higher education) Mjob - mother's job (nominal: 'teacher', 'health' care related, civil 'services' (e.g. administrative police), 'at_home' '') Fjob - father's job (nominal: 'teacher', 'health' care related, civil 'services' (e.g. administrative police), 'at_home' '') reason - reason choose school (nominal: close 'home', school 'reputation', 'course' preference '') guardian - student's guardian (nominal: 'mother', 'father' '') traveltime - home school travel time (numeric: 1 - <15 min., 2 - 15 30 min., 3 - 30 min. 1 hour, 4 - >1 hour) studytime - weekly study time (numeric: 1 - <2 hours, 2 - 2 5 hours, 3 - 5 10 hours, 4 - >10 hours) failures - number past class failures (numeric: n 1<=n<3, else 4) schoolsup - extra educational support (binary: yes ) famsup - family educational support (binary: yes ) paid - extra paid classes within course subject (Math Portuguese) (binary: yes ) activities - extra-curricular activities (binary: yes ) nursery - attended nursery school (binary: yes ) higher - wants take higher education (binary: yes ) internet - Internet access home (binary: yes ) romantic - romantic relationship (binary: yes ) famrel - quality family relationships (numeric: 1 - bad 5 - excellent) freetime - free time school (numeric: 1 - low 5 - high) goout - going friends (numeric: 1 - low 5 - high) Dalc - workday alcohol consumption (numeric: 1 - low 5 - high) Walc - weekend alcohol consumption (numeric: 1 - low 5 - high) health - current health status (numeric: 1 - bad 5 - good) absences - number school absences (numeric: 0 93) grades related course subject, Math Portuguese: G1 - first period grade (numeric: 0 20) G2 - second period grade (numeric: 0 20) G3 - final grade (numeric: 0 20, output target)
